Chapter on Two Dharmas (3-5)
I heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!

And is not moderate in food and drink, one will become unbelieving and lazy.
In this present life, one's body and mind will experience much suffering,
And there will be calamities, afflictions, troubles, and burning;
Whether walking, standing, sitting, lying down, awake, or dreaming,
Because of these two causes and conditions, one will always have offenses and be blamed.
Whether living in a village or in solitude, in a crowd or in a quiet place,

I heard this from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are two kinds of dharmas that can give rise to burning distress.
What are the two?

It is like a certain person who only creates many evils, only does reckless and violent things, only gives rise to defilement and impurity, does not cultivate many wholesome things, does not practice gentleness and flexibility, and does not rescue those in fear. Later, when their body is afflicted by a serious illness, and the entire body experiences extremely intense and severe pain, they are about to die in agony, and there is no medical treatment that can save them.
When experiencing this suffering, they moan and lament, thinking:

'From the past until now, I have only created many evils, only acted recklessly and wildly, only given rise to defilements, not cultivated many wholesome deeds, not practiced gentleness and humility, not rescued those in fear.

If sentient beings only create many evils, only act recklessly and wildly, only give rise to defilements, not cultivate wholesome deeds, not practice gentleness and humility, not rescue those in fear, then wherever they go, I will definitely go as well.

' Because of only creating many evils and so forth, their minds become scorched and distressed, and because of not cultivating wholesome deeds and so forth, their minds become scorched and distressed.
These are called the two kinds of dharmas that can give rise to scorching and distress.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning of this and spoke a verse, saying:
There are two dharmas that can give rise to the scorching and distress of the foolish mind,
Namely, only creating sinful karma and not cultivating the causes of blessings and virtues.
Later, when suffering from illness, they moan and lament,
Regretting having sins and lacking blessings, their minds burn with remorse.
Those with sins and no blessings are born in various evil realms,
I will also definitely follow them, there is no doubt.
I have heard the World-Honored One say:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are two kinds of dharmas that do not cause the mind to burn with distress.
What are the two?

It is said that there is a type of person who only cultivates various wholesome deeds, only practices gentleness and compassion, only rescues those in fear, does not create various evils, does not act recklessly or wildly, and does not give rise to defilements. Later, when their body is afflicted by a serious illness, intense and severe pain arises all over the body, and the agony is about to end, with no medical treatment available.
When experiencing this suffering, although they may moan, they do not lament. They think like this:

'From the past until now, I have only cultivated various wholesome deeds, only practiced gentleness, and only rescued those in fear. I have not created various evils, acted recklessly, or given rise to defilements.

If sentient beings only cultivate various wholesome deeds, only practice gentleness, and only rescue those in fear, not creating various evils, not acting recklessly, and not giving rise to defilements, then wherever they go, I will definitely follow.'
Because of only cultivating various wholesome deeds and so forth, their minds are not tormented. And because of not creating various evils and so forth, their minds are not tormented.
These are called the two kinds of dharmas that do not torment the mind.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
There are two dharmas that can give rise to joy in the wise ones' minds,
Namely, only cultivating meritorious karma and not creating causes for offenses.
Later, when encountering the suffering of illness, moaning without resentment or lamentation,
Rejoicing in blessings and having no offenses, one does not regret or burn with distress.
For those with blessings and no offenses, wherever they are born in the good destinies,
I will also definitely follow and go there, without any doubt.
I have heard thus:

Without difficult and difficult practices, having sharp faculties,
Therefore, the Great Sage is called the path of joyful swift spiritual powers.
Having difficult and difficult practices, having sharp faculties,
Therefore, the Great Sage is called the path of painful swift spiritual powers.

I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:

I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:

And will ascend to the good destinies, being reborn in the heavens.
I have heard thus:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that there are two kinds of sublime cognition that should be cultivated to arise;

One can attain what has not been attained, can touch what has not been touched, can realize what has not been realized, can transcend sorrow and lamentation, can extinguish worry and suffering, can accord with the right principle, can obtain immortality, and can realize nirvÄá¹‡a.

When the cognition of dharmas arises, one is able to thoroughly know conditioned phenomena without error.
Having thoroughly known conditioned phenomena, one is able to prevent the causes that give rise to future existence from arising, increasing, and expanding.
When the cognition of categories arises, one is able to truly eliminate ignorance;ğŸ”½Because ignorance is eliminated, there is no more conceptual proliferation;
Because there is no conceptual proliferation, there is no more investigation and analysis;
Because there is no investigation and analysis, there is no desire;
Because there is no desire, there is no love or hatred;
Because there is no love or hatred, there is no stinginess or jealousy;

Because there are no such evil and unwholesome dharmas, karma that leads to rebirth does not increase;
Because karma that leads to rebirth does not increase, all karma is extinguished;
Because karma is extinguished, all suffering is extinguished;
Because suffering is extinguished, the path of birth and death is cut off.
When this path is cut off, one naturally knows:

One can attain what has not been attained, can touch what has not been touched, can realize what has not been realized, can transcend sorrow and lamentation, can extinguish grief and suffering, can accord with the right principle, can obtain immortality, and can realize nirvana.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
There are two kinds of wondrous cognition, which should be cultivated and generated,
Capable of attaining what has not been attained, and so forth, namely the cognition of dharmas and the cognition of categories.
When the cognition of dharmas arises, one thoroughly knows conditioned dharmas,
And can cause the causes of subsequent existence not to arise or increase.
When the cognition of categories arises, ignorance is then eliminated,
And by this, the cycle of birth and death is severed.
One knows by oneself that one's births are ended, and that the holy life has been established,
That what was to be done has all been accomplished, and that one will not undergo another existence.
I heard this from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know:
There are two kinds of wondrous cognition, which one should properly contemplate, properly measure, and properly observe;

One can attain what has not been attained, can touch what has not been touched, can realize what has not been realized, can transcend sorrow and lamentation, can extinguish worry and suffering, can accord with right principle, can obtain immortality, and can realize nirvana.
What are the two?
They are mundane cognition and supramundane cognition.
As for mundane cognition, it means correctly knowing and understanding in the form aggregate that this is the form aggregate;
It is the same in the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
In the earth element, one correctly knows and understands that this is the earth element;
It is the same in the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements.
In the eye element, one correctly knows and understands that this is the eye element; It is the same in the form element and eye-consciousness element.
In the ear element, one correctly knows and understands that this is the ear element; It is the same in the sound element and ear-consciousness element.
Regarding the nose realm, they are able to accurately understand it as the nose realm, and the same is so regarding the olfactory realm and olfactory consciousness realm;
Regarding the tongue realm, they are able to accurately understand it as the tongue realm, and the same is so regarding the gustatory realm and gustatory consciousness realm;
Regarding the body realm, they are able to accurately understand it as the body realm, and the same is so regarding the tactile realm and tactile consciousness realm;
Regarding the mind realm, they are able to accurately understand it as the mind realm, and the same is so regarding the dharma realm and mental consciousness realm.

Regarding such conventional dharmas, in this way and that way, they accurately understand them as they really are, with knowledge, insight, wisdom, realization, and complete illumination, which is called worldly knowledge.
The noble disciples, regarding this explained worldly knowledge, should properly investigate, should properly measure, should properly contemplate:
When this worldly knowledge is being properly cultivated, can it cause sentient beings with the nature of birth to be permanently liberated from birth?
Can it cause those with the nature of aging to be permanently liberated from aging?
The same applies to the natures of illness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and anxiety.
Having carefully examined this, one is able to correctly understand:

When this worldly knowledge is being properly cultivated, it cannot cause those with the nature of birth to be permanently liberated from birth, and it cannot cause those with the nature of aging to be permanently liberated from aging. The same applies to the natures of illness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and anxiety.
Why is this?

This worldly knowledge is not the Dharma of the noble ones, not the means to permanent liberation, not the path to nirvÄá¹‡a, not the means to permanent dispassion, not the means to permanent freedom, not the means to permanent cessation, not the means to permanent peace, not true transcendent knowledge, not right perfect enlightenment, and not the realization of nirvÄá¹‡a;
it is the Dharma that leads to rebirth, the Dharma that leads to old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and anxiety.
When they contemplate, measure, and carefully investigate in this way, they dwell in the notion of fear regarding worldly dharmas and in the notion of tranquility regarding supramundane dharmas.
Because they fear the world, they do not grasp at anything at all;
because they do not grasp, craving does not arise;
because of the absence of craving, they personally experience ultimate nirvÄá¹‡a.
Having realized nirvÄá¹‡a, they know for themselves:
My births have been ended, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, there will be no more of this mundane existence.
This is called the correct contemplation, correct evaluation, and correct observation of the wisdom of this world.

Supramundane wisdom refers to the correct understanding of all aggregates, realms, and sense bases, knowing that these dharmas are impermanent, suffering, sick, festering, arrow-like, harmful, fearful, hot, decaying, ceasing, calamitous, accidental, epidemic, empty, false, void, deceptive, lacking a real self, and unreliable.
Correctly understanding these natures of dharmas with wisdom, insight, discernment, realization, and thorough illumination is called supramundane wisdom.
The noble disciples should correctly contemplate, evaluate, and observe the supramundane wisdom as explained here:
When this supramundane cognition is being cultivated, can it cause those beings who are subject to birth to be forever freed from birth?
Can it cause those beings who are subject to aging to be forever freed from aging?
The same applies to the dharmas of sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and vexation.
Having carefully examined this, one is able to understand correctly:

When this supramundane cognition is being cultivated, it can definitely cause those beings who are subject to birth to be forever freed from birth, and it can definitely cause those beings who are subject to aging to be forever freed from aging, as well as the dharmas of sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and vexation.
Why is this?

This supramundane cognition is the Dharma of the sages, which can lead to permanent liberation, which is the path to nirvÄá¹‡a, which can lead to permanent disgust, separation, cessation, and tranquility. It is true and perfect cognition, which can realize nirvÄá¹‡a;
It is not a dharma that produces birth, nor a dharma that produces aging, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, or unrest.
When they contemplate, measure, and carefully investigate in this way, they give rise to the notion of a precious treasure towards supramundane dharmas;
Towards worldly dharmas, they give rise to the notion of being lowly.
Because they give rise to precious treasures in the supramundane, they give rise to joy;
Because they give rise to joy, their minds are at ease;
Because their minds are at ease, their bodies attain lightness and comfort;
Because their bodies are light and comfortable, they experience blissful pleasure;
Because they experience blissful pleasure, their minds attain tranquility;
Because their minds are tranquil, they are able to truly know and see;
Because they truly know and see, they are able to deeply detest and turn away from;
Because of deeply detesting and turning away from [the world], one is able to correctly abandon desires;
Because of correctly abandoning desires, one is able to attain liberation.
Having attained liberation, one then knows for oneself:
My births have been exhausted, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, and I will not experience another existence.
This is called correctly contemplating, correctly measuring, and correctly observing within this supramundane cognition.
This is called the two kinds of wondrous cognition, which should be correctly contemplated, correctly measured, and correctly observed;

One can attain what has not been attained, can touch what has not been touched, can realize what has not been realized, can transcend sorrow and lamentation, can extinguish worry and suffering, can accord with the right principle, can obtain immortality, and can realize nirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
There are two kinds of wondrous cognition, which the wise should contemplate,
Namely, the mundane and supramundane, which can correctly end all suffering.
One should contemplate worldly wisdom, giving rise to the thought of fear,
Totally without any clinging, one will attain nirvana one after another;
One should contemplate supramundane wisdom, giving rise to the thought of precious jewels,
By this, one will give rise to joy, and then attain physical ease.
Because of ease, one is delighted and blissful; because of delight and bliss, the mind becomes concentrated;
Because the mind attains concentration, one is then able to give rise to the factors of enlightenment;
The factors of enlightenment contemplate the noble truths, forever severing the net of doubts,
Without doubt, without grasping, forever liberated from the edge of all suffering.
